data.summary: Health officials confirmed on 26 February 2020 that the first case of COVID-19 was detected in a patient in Thessaloniki who had recently returned from northern Italy. Following a countrywide lockdown, authorities began lifting restrictions in stages in May 2020 and allowed international travel to resume. Most COVID-19 lockdown measures were lifted on 14 May 2021; the country reopened to vaccinated travellers from most countries in a bit to resume tourism.

areaRestrictions.text: Until 06:00 local time on 16 September, a 01:00-06:00 local time curfew is in effect in Heraklion, Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Argolida and Evrytania regional units, and the municipality of Ikaria. Travel will be only permitted for going to work, attending a medical appointment or compelling reasons.

Officials extended restrictions on domestic flights until 13 September. Travel to and from the country's islands requires presenting a COVID-19 vaccination certificate with at least 14 days since the second dose, proof of recovery issued between 2-9 months before travel or a negative PCR test result no older than 72 hour or a rapid antigen test no older than 48 hours.

From 13 September, all unvaccinated individuals travelling by plane, boat, bus, or train must present a rapid antigen test no older than 48 hours before departure; tests will cost EUR10 (USD11,75).

Hospitality establishments are permitted to provide outdoor service. Restaurants, bars and nightlife establishments are permitted to provide service to seated guests only.

From 16 July-13 September, only fully vaccinated individuals will be allowed to enter indoor venues, including restaurants, cinemas and theatres.

Until 16 September, private gatherings with more than 20 people and music in public venues are not permitted in Heraklion, Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Argolida and Evrytania regional units, and the municipality of Ikaria.

From 31 August, individuals must present either a proof of vaccination or a certificate about recent recovery from COVID-19 or a negative PCR test result issued within 72 hours to visit public venues, including exhibitions and conferences.

Starting 13 September, only those with proof of vaccination or recovery from COVID-19 will be permitted to enter indoor cafes, restaurants, clubs and sports venues. Customers without COVID-19 certificates must present a negative PCR test that was taken within 48 hours for entry to cinemas, theaters, museums and gyms. Unvaccinated university students must take COVID-19 tests twice a week. Rapid tests will cost 10EUR.

Police officers fired riot control agents to disperse demonstrators who rallied on Nea Smyrni Square in Athens on 7 March to protest police violence following earlier confrontations between officers and bystanders over the enforcement of COVID-19 social distancing restrictions. Protests have continued in other cities over the restrictions including Thessaloniki.

transportation.text: International flights are available at Athens (ATH/LGAV) and other airports across the country.

declarationDocuments.text: All international travellers must complete a Passenger Locator Form at least 24 hours before their planned travel.

entry.text:
Travellers from the European Union (EU) and the Schengen Area, as well as Albania, Andorra, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Belarus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, China, Israel, Japan, Jordan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Lebanon, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, New Zealand, North Macedonia, Qatar, Russia, San Marino, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Turkey, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates (UAE), United Kingdom (UK), United States (US) and the Vatican are permitted entry without quarantine, provided that they present proof of a negative test, full vaccination or recovery from COVID-19. Entry from other countries is only permitted for health professionals and others making essential travel.

Entry through land borders is possible through Promachonas, Ormenio, Evzonoi, Nymfaia, Niki, Doirani, Kristallopigi, Kipi, Kakavia, Kastanies and Exohi 24 hours a day.

Cruises and yachts are permitted, while maritime links with Turkey remain restricted.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Before travel

Arriving unvaccinated travellers from all countries must present a negative PCR test that was taken within 72 hours before arrival or a rapid antigen test no older than 48 hours before arrival, unless they have proof of vaccination or recovery from COVID-19.

Arrivals from Russia must present a negative COVID-19 test, regardless of vaccination status.

Upon arrival

Unvaccinated travellers arriving from Egypt, Albania, Argentina, Bulgaria, Brazil, Georgia, Cuba, United Arab Emirates, India, China, Libya, Morocco, North Macedonia, Pakistan, Russia and Turkey must take a rapid test upon arrival.

Random rapid antigen testing will be carried out at ports of entry; travellers who test positive must quarantine. Those who refuse health checks can be denied entry. Those who test positive at the country's land borders can be denied entry as well.

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

quarantineModality.text:
Travellers from the European Union (EU) and the Schengen Area, as well as the United States (US), United Kingdom (UK), the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Serbia, Israel, Australia, New Zealand, South Korea, Singapore, North Macedonia, Canada, Belarus, Bahrain, Qatar, China, Kuwait, Turkey, Ukraine, Saudi Arabia, Russia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Japan, Albania, Lebanon, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Brunei and Moldova, Andorra, Jordan, Kosovo, Monaco, San Marino, Taiwan and The Vatican are exempt from quarantine, provided that they present proof of a negative COVID-19 test result, full vaccination or recovery from the virus.

Travellers from Montenegro are exempt from quarantine, provided they present both a negative COVID-19 test result and a full vaccination certificate.

Those who test positive for COVID-19 during random testing at the border must quarantine at a designated hotel for up to 10 days, regardless of the country of departure. Vaccinated travellers who test positive must quarantine for seven days.

mask.text: Face masks must be worn in indoor spaces. Mask-wearing is mandatory in crowded public places; a fine of up to EUR300 (USD354) can be imposed for non-compliance.

exit.text: There are no special requirements to exit the country, with the exception of a Passenger Locator Form that all international travellers must complete.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Vaccinated travellers are exempt from quarantine and testing, provided that they present proof of full vaccination. At least 14 days must have passed since the final dose. As of 30 June, testing requirements will be reinstituted for vaccinated travellers from Russia.

Proof of recovery from COVID-19 must have been issued between 2-9 months prior to travel for exemption from testing and quarantine.

All documentation must have been issued in English, German French, Italian, Spanish or Russian.

Residents who have been vaccinated against COVID-19, recovered from a prior infection or recently tested negative for the virus can obtain EU Digital COVID Certificates on the government portal (https://www.gov.gr/ipiresies/ugeia-kai-pronoia/koronoios-covid-19/greencertificate).
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Sinopharm Phase 1 - 14 days after second dose.
Sputnik V - 14 days after second dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 60 days, not older than 9 months.

areaPolicy.text: High COVID-19 incidence areas are subject to stricter measures, including a nightly curfew.

data.summary: Health officials confirmed on 24 January 2020 that three cases of COVID-19 were detected in Paris and Bordeaux, the first cases to be confirmed in the European Union (EU). The outbreak has resulted in one of the highest number of deaths in Europe and prompted three nationwide lockdowns. After initially lifting most health measures, officials declared in July 2021 that the country entered a fourth wave of the pandemic. The country's southern regions have especially seen a sharp uptick in new cases due to the spread of the delta virus variant.

areaRestrictions.text: A COVID-19 health pass is mandatory for long-distance journeys on buses, planes and trains, including TGV, Intercity trains and long-distance coaches.

A COVID-19 health pass (pass sanitaire) is required for access to large events with more than 1,000 people in the audience, as well as cultural and leisure spaces with more than 50 people. The requirement to present a health pass also applies to cafes, restaurants and long-distance travel. In departments where the COVID-19 incidence rate exceeds 200 cases per 100,000 inhabitants, the health pass is also required for entering large shopping centres that are more than 20,000 sq metres in size.

The health pass is available to those who can prove vaccination, recovery or a negative test for COVID-19 in one of the three following ways: a COVID-19 vaccine administered in the European Union (EU), a positive PCR or antigen test issued between 11 days-6 months or a negative PCR, antigen or supervised self-test result that was obtained 72 hours prior to application. The pass can be obtained from the TousAntiCovid app. COVID-19 tests are free until mid-October.

Non-EU travellers can obtain a health pass by taking a PCR test in France or requesting it by email with a completed application and copies of their passport, vaccination certificate and travel ticket. The vaccine must be recognised by the European Medicines Agency (EMA). Further details are available on the French government website (https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/coming-to-france/coronavirus-advice-for-foreign-nationals-in-france/coronavirus-statements/article/applying-for-a-covid-certificate-if-you-were-vaccinated-abroad-procedure-for).

French nationals and residents who have been vaccinated in a non-EU country, except Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, the United Kingdom (UK) and Switzerland, can request a health pass online, provided that the vaccine is recognised by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) (https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/le-ministere-et-son-reseau/actualites-du-ministere/informations-coronavirus-covid-19/coronavirus-declarations-et-communiques/article/communique-passe-sanitaire-pour-les-francais-de-l-etranger-et-leurs-ayants).

Multiple clashes with police officers occurred during the first lockdown period in urban hubs, primarily communes on the outskirts of Paris including Villeneuve-la-Garenne, Clichy, Rueil-Malmaison, Asni√®res, Nanterre, Meudon, Clamart and Gennevilliers.

Health care workers have held protests to demand greater protection and higher compensation, while demonstrations have also been held over the economic impact of the pandemic. On 25 September 2020, workers in the hospitality sector in Marseille held a rally against the government's decision to close bars and restaurants in the city. Renewed protest against COVID-19 restrictions were held in late October 2020 in Paris, Toulouse, Montpellier and Nantes. In July and August 2021, demonstrations were held in protest of government plans to expand the mandatory use of the COVID-19 health pass in public spaces. These demonstrations have the potential to escalate to widespread unrest and disruptive strike actions unless authorities are able to successfully negotiate with workers on their demands.
On 17 December 2020, President Emmanuel Macron tested positive for COVID-19. Several French, Spanish and European Union Council officials went into self-isolation following the positive result.

transportation.text: Major hubs are open. Air France and other carriers are operating flights with reduced capacity.

declarationDocuments.text: All travellers wishing to enter France, including nationals, are required to complete and present a sworn statement confirming that they do not have COVID-19 symptoms, they are not aware of contact with a confirmed case of COVID-19 within the last 14 days and they will be compliant with testing or quarantine requirements upon arrival.

entry.text:
Vaccinated travellers from all countries are permitted entry regardless of their purpose of travel.

The country is open to travel from "green" countries - European Union (EU) member states, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland and the Vatican, as well as Albania, Australia, Bahrain, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, Chile, Comoros, Hong Kong, Israel, Japan, Jordan, Kosovo, Lebanon, Montenegro, New Zealand, North Macedonia, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Ukraine, Uruguay, the United States of America (USA) and Vanuatu. Travellers from "green" countries are permitted entry regardless of their purpose of travel or vaccination status.

Non-essential travel is not permitted for unvaccinated travellers from "orange" countries - all other countries that are not "green". Unvaccinated travellers from "orange" countries must continue to demonstrate a compelling reason for travel to be permitted entry.

Unvaccinated foreign nationals are not permitted entry from high COVID-19 risk "red" countries - Afghanistan, Algeria, Argentina, Bangladesh, Brazil, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Democratic Republic of Congo, Georgia, Indonesia, Iran, Maldives, Morocco, Mozambique, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Russia, Seychelles, South Africa, Suriname, Tunisia and Turkey- unless they have compelling reasons for travel. Residents of France and family members of French nationals will continue to be permitted entry, regardless of their vaccination status.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Unvaccinated travellers from "green" countries must present a negative PCR or antigen test that was taken within 72 hours before departure. Those who reside within 30km of the French border are exempt, provided that the duration of their travel does not exceed 24 hours. Hauliers and those who are making work-related trips and cannot take COVID-19 tests due to the frequent or urgent nature of their travel are also exempt.

Unvaccinated travellers arriving from Cyprus, Greece, the Netherlands, Spain, Portugal, Malta must present a negative PCR or antigen test that was taken within 24 hours before boarding.

Unvaccinated travellers from "orange" countries must present a negative PCR test no older than 72 hours or an antigen test no older than 48 hours.

Unvaccinted travellers from the United Kingdom (UK) must present a ngative PCR test no older than 24 hours before boarding.

Unvaccinated travellers arriving from "red" countries must present a negative PCR or antigen test result no older than 48 hours at the time of boarding.

Upon arrival

Unvaccinated travellers arriving from "red" countries must take an additional COVID-19 test at the airport.

Unvaccinated travellers from "orange" countries can also be subject to COVID-19 testing upon arrival.
diseaseTesting.testType: PCR, Antigen, PCR, Antigen, PCR, Antigen

tracingApplication.text: "Tous Anti-Covid" is an optional mobile app for contact tracing.

quarantineModality.text:
Unvaccinated travellers from "orange" countries must self-quarantine for seven days.

Unvaccinated travellers arriving from "red" countries must undergo a supervised quarantine for 10 days. Before boarding, travellers must present to their carrier a proof of address where they plan to undergo quarantine; airlines can refuse boarding to passengers deemed to have insufficient documentation.

All vaccinated travellers arriving from "green", "orange" and "red" countries are exempt from quarantine.

mask.text:
Face masks are mandatory on public transport and in enclosed public areas. Face masks must be also worn at markets, stadiums, queues and other crowded outdoor spaces when distancing is not possible. In high-incidence areas where the infection rate exceeds 200 cases per 100,000 inhabitants, face masks must be also worn in indoor spaces where a health pass is required for entry.

Face masks must be worn inflight. A disposable, surgical-type mask must be worn when onboard planes; passengers wearing reusable face masks have been denied boarding. Air France passengers are asked to wear a surgical mask from the moment they arrive at the airport and for the duration of the flight.

exit.text:
Unvaccinated travellers seeking to travel to an "orange" country - any country not on the "green" or "red" list - must complete a certificate of international travel (https://www.interieur.gouv.fr/Actualites/L-actu-du-Ministere/Certificate-of-international-travel). Travel to one's country of origin or residence will continue to be permitted.

All travel to "red" countries is strongly discouraged. Both unvaccinated and vaccinated travellers must complete a certificate of international travel (https://www.interieur.gouv.fr/Actualites/L-actu-du-Ministere/Certificate-of-international-travel).

diseaseVaccination.text:
Fully vaccinated travellers arriving from "green", "orange" and "red" list countries are exempt from all travel requirements before and upon arrival in France. Proof of vaccination is required in the form of a paper certificate or via the notebook function of the TousAntiCovid app.

Those who have been vaccinated or recovered from COVID-19 can obtain a health pass (pass sanitaire) through mobile app TousAntiCovid (https://bonjour.tousanticovid.gouv.fr/) for access to large events. The vaccine must be approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) and administered in the EU. At least 14 days must have passed since the final dose of a two-dose vaccine and at least 28 days must have passed for a single-dose vaccine. For those who received a vaccine after recovering from the virus, proof of vaccination is also valid after more than 7 days passed since the first dose. Proof of recovery is valid between 11-180 days after a positive COVID-19 test was issued.
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 28 days after first dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 11 days, not older than 6 months.
diseaseVaccination.exemptions: Entry Ban, Testing, Quarantine, Domestic Restrictions

areaPolicy.text: Under the fourth and final step of reopening, restrictions on large events were relaxed and local authorities were given power to decide COVID-19 measures on a wider range of issues.

data.summary: Public health officials confirmed the first two COVID-19 cases in England on 31 January 2020. While a mass vaccination campaign has significantly reduced the number of deaths, the country has seen a sharp uptick in COVID-19 cases driven by the spread of the delta virus variant. Despite high incidence rates, most distancing measures have been lifted.

areaRestrictions.text:
Covid domestic travel policies and advice for:

  • England
  • Scotland
  • Wales
  • Northern Ireland

Northern Ireland

Up to 15 people from four households are permitted to gather in a domestic setting. A one-metre minimum distancing is mandatory in indoor venues.

Scotland

Starting 1 October, a COVID-19 health pass will be required for entering nightlife establishments and large public events. The requirement is expected to apply to unseated indoor live events with more than 500 people in the audience, unseated outdoor live events with more than 4,000 people in the audience and events of any kind with more than 10,000 people present.
Large rallies that have ended in clashes with police have been held in London, Belfast, Manchester, Edinburgh, Leeds, Glasgow, Brighton and other cities to protest lockdown measures.

transportation.text:
Most available long-haul flights are operating at London Heathrow Airport (LHR/EGLL). Multiple carriers including British Airways are gradually increasing their flight schedule.

Flights from Argentina, Bangladesh, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Egypt, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Kenya, Maldives, Oman, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Tunisia or Turkey are permitted to land at dedicated terminals of London Heathrow (LHR/EGLL) or Birmingham International (BHX/EGBB) airports only.

British Airways suspended all passenger flights between the United Kingdom and Mexico from 15 August to 30 September.

declarationDocuments.text: Arriving travellers must complete and submit a passenger locator form within 48 hours before arrival. Travellers who are arriving from Ireland, the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man and stayed there for at least 10 days are not required to complete the form.

entry.text:
Those who have travelled to or through Afghanistan, Angola, Argentina, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Botswana, Brazil, Burundi, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, Eritrea, Eswatini, Ethiopia, French Guiana, Georgia, Guyana, Haiti, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Maldives, Mayotte, Mexico, Mongolia, Montenegro, Mozambique, Myanmar, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Philippines, Reuniion, Rwanda, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Somalia, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Sudan, Suriname, Tanzania, Thailand, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia, Turkey, Uganda, Uruguay, Venezuela, Zambia or Zimbabwe in the last 10 days are not permitted to enter.

Only nationals of the UK and Ireland, UK permanent residents and UK long-term visa holders will be permitted entry from these countries.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Arriving travellers must present a negative COVID-19 test result not older than three days before the time of departure, regardless of vaccination status. Arrivals from the Common Travel Area (Jersey, Guernsey, the Isle of Man and Ireland), children under the age of 11 and hauliers are exempt. Consult the government website for a full list of testing exemptions (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules).

After arrival

Travellers must book a post-arrival COVID-19 testing package online (https://quarantinehotelbookings.ctmportal.co.uk/) at their own expense.

Travellers returning from "green list" countries must take an additional PCR test on or before day 2 after arrival. Vaccinated UK travellers returning from abroad and vaccinated travellers from the United States and the European Union must also take a Day 2 test.

Other travellers arriving from an "amber list" country and all travellers returning from a "red list" country must take PCR tests on days 2 and 8 during quarantine.

As part of the 'test to release' scheme, travellers arriving in England from an "amber list" country can take a COVID-19 test five days after entry to shorten the self-quarantine period. Travellers wishing to be tested must do so at their own expense. Travellers must continue to take COVID-19 tests on day 2 and 8 of their stay, regardless of the test result taken as part of the 'test to release' scheme. Travellers arriving from "red list" countries are excluded from the scheme.

tracingApplication.text: Optional contact tracing app "NHS COVID-19" is available for use in England and Wales, "StopCOVID NI" in Northern Ireland and "Protect Scotland" in Scotland.

quarantineModality.text:
Quarantine is mandatory for travellers, excluding those arriving from "green list" areas and vaccinated travellers arriving from some "amber list" areas. For travel from Portugal, quarantine exemptions only apply to arrivals from the Azores or Madeira.

Travellers from "amber list" countries must quarantine for 10 days at home. Vaccinated UK travellers returning from abroad and vaccinated travellers arriving from "amber" countries in the European Union (EU) or the United States (US) are exempt from quarantine.

Travellers who arrive from or stayed in "red list" countries must undergo hotel quarantine at a designated facility for 10 days. The requirement also applies to those who transited through a "red list" country. Travellers arriving from "red list" countries must book a hotel and testing package at their own expense (https://quarantinehotelbookings.ctmportal.co.uk/). The quarantine costs GBP1,750 for the first traveller staying in a room.

Workers in healthcare and other select sectors are exempt from quarantine. Consult the government website (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules) for further details on quarantine requirements by sector.

England

As part of the "test to release" scheme, travellers may opt to take a test five days into their self-quarantine and leave early, pending a negative test result within 24-48 hours. The testing scheme is not available to travellers arriving from "red list" countries subject to entry bans.

mask.text:
Wearing a face mask is mandatory in public transport and other enclosed public spaces in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

In England, the use of face masks is recommended in crowded areas. Businesses and travel operators can set their own mask requirements. The use of face masks remains mandatory on public transport operated by Transport for London (TfL).

British Airways passengers are asked to wear a mask from the moment they arrive at the airport until they leave the plane at their destination.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Fully vaccinated travellers arriving from "amber" countries are exempt from quarantine, provided that they were vaccinated in the United Kingdom (UK), an EU member state, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, Vatican City or the United States (US). The vaccine must be recognised by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), European Medicines Agency (EMA) or Swissmedic. To be considered fully vaccinated, travellers must have received two doses of the same vaccine and at least 14 days must have passed since the final dose. Travellers who received one dose of an approved single-dose vaccine are also considered fully vaccinated.

Fully vaccinated travellers arriving from all countries must continue to be tested before departure and on Day 2 after arrival.

Those travelling abroad from Wales or England can present the NHS Covid Pass (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/covid-pass/get-your-covid-pass-letter/) as a digital app or in a letter form as proof of full vaccination from COVID-19. Those travelling from Northern Ireland (https://www.nidirect.gov.uk/services/coronavirus-covid-19-interim-proof-vaccination-document) or Scotland (https://www.nhsinform.scot/covid19status) can obtain the certificate in written form.
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.

areaPolicy.text: Most social distancing measures were lifted in August 2021.

data.summary: Sweden confirmed its first novel coronavirus (COVID-19) case on 31 January 2020 after a traveller from Wuhan, China, tested positive for the virus in J√∂nk√∂ping County. Sweden responded to the outbreak with a relatively lax approach, being one of the few countries without mandatory mask use in public spaces. While sanitary measures are being eased in stages, the country's COVID-19 laws remain in effect until January 2022.

areaRestrictions.text: Private gatherings are permitted for up to 50 people. On 29 September, limits on the size of public and private events will be lifted.
Prince Carl Philip and Princess Sofia tested postive for COVID-19 on 26 November 2020.
Clashes erupted during a march from Stockholm's Medborgarplatsen in March 2021 between police and anti-lockdown demonstrators.

transportation.text: Scandinavian Airlines (SAS), the main airline serving the country, is operating flights through Stockholm Arlanda Airport (ARN/ESSA) primarily to destinations in Scandinavia and major hubs in Europe. Long-haul service is available on a limited number of routes, including ones linking Stockholm to destinations in the United States, China and the United Arab Emirates.

entry.text:
An entry ban is in effect for travellers arriving from a country outside the European Union (EU) and the Schengen Area until 31 October. Nationals of Sweden and other European Economic Area (EEA) countries and residents of Albania, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, Hong Kong, Japan, Jordan, Macau, Moldova, New Zealand, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan and Ukraine are exempt and permitted to enter.

Exemptions are also made for those with an essential need or function in Sweden, returning Swedish residents and new residency or student permit holders who are to moving to Sweden. Travellers considered to have an essential purpose include health care professionals, workers transporting goods and passengers travelling for imperative family reasons. The decision to grant an exemption will be made at the border upon arrival; police do not issue prior approvals.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

EU travellers - excluding residents of Sweden and travellers from Denmark, Finland, Norway and Iceland - must present the EU Digital COVID Certificate or equivalent documentation as proof of a negative COVID-19 test, recovery or vaccination. The test must have been taken within 72 hours before entry. Cross-border commuters must present a negative COVID-19 test that is no older than one week.

Swedish nationals and others exempt from pre-departure testing are advised to be tested as soon as possible after arrival and take a second test on Day 5. Testing centres can be found on website https://www.1177.se/.

Non-EU travellers are required to present a negative PCR, LAMP, TMA or antigen test for COVID-19 no older than 48 hours before arrival.
diseaseTesting.testType: PCR, Antigen, LAMP, TMA, PCR, Antigen, LAMP, TMA

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

quarantineModality.text: There is no requirement for international arrivals to quarantine. However, non-EU arrivals are recommended to self-quarantine for up to seven days and avoid close contact with others.

mask.text: SAS passengers must wear face medical masks while on board. Travellers showing symptoms of COVID-19 will be denied boarding.

exit.text: Non-essential travel to countries outside the EU, the Schengen Area and the UK is discouraged until 15 October. The advice does not apply to travel to non-EU countries that are exempt from Sweden's entry ban.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Travellers who present the EU Digital COVID Certificate (EUDCC) or other valid proof of recovery or vaccination against COVID-19 are exempt from testing. Proof of vaccination or recovery is only valid for entry or transit from another EEA country.

Vaccination certificates must have been issued in an EEA country, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Switzerland, the Vatican or a "safe" non-EU country to be considered valid. The vaccine must have been approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) or the World Health Organization (WHO) for emergency use.

Proof of recovery must be issued in an EEA country, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino, Switzerland or the Vatican to be considered valid.
qualifiedVaccines: AstraZeneca (South Korea) - 14 days after second dose.
Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Sinopharm Phase 1 - 14 days after second dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 11 days, not older than 6 months.

areaPolicy.text: As part of a five-step reopening plan, social distancing requirements and limits on gatherings are being lifted gradually. Most COVID-19 measures will be lifted on 29 September.

data.summary: The COVID-19 outbreak in Spain caused one of the highest number of deaths in Europe. In January 2021, the total number of cases in the country surpassed 2 million. While most restrictions have been eased following the end of the state of alarm in May 2021, thousands of new cases continue to be reported daily.

areaRestrictions.text: A negative COVID-19 test is required for travel to the Balearic Islands and the Canary Islands. Travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 or have been vaccinated against the virus are exempt.

Hundreds of demonstrators rallied on Puerta del Sol and outside the Assembly of Madrid in Puente de Vallecas on 27 September 2020 to protest lockdown measures in the capital. In October and November 2020, clashes erupted between demonstrators and police officers in Barcelona, Seville, Le√≥n, Logro√±o and Vitoria-Gasteiz during protests against the goverment's decision to impose a nighttime curfew. Further protests are possible, particularly in urban hubs.

transportation.text: International flights are operating at major airports, including Barcelona-El Prat (BCN/LEBL), Madrid‚ÄìBarajas (MAD/LEMD), Ibiza (IBZ/LEIB), Menorca (MAH/LEMH), Tenerife South (TFS/GCTS), Alicante-Elche (ALC/LEAL), Region of Murcia (RMU/LEMI), Sevilla (SVQ/LEZL), M√°laga (AGP/LEMG), Palma de Mallorca (PMI/LEPA) and Gran Canaria (LPA/GCLP).

declarationDocuments.text:
Travellers arriving by air must complete a health control form (https://www.spth.gob.es/) 48 hours prior to travel and obtain a QR code to present upon arrival. The form can be also completed on the mobile app "Spain Travel Health APP".

Travellers arriving by sea must complete a separate form (https://spthm.puertos.es/).

Travellers arriving in Galicia must provide contact details by completing a form (https://coronavirus.sergas.gal/viaxeiros/?ling=en) if they visited a high COVID-19 risk area in the last 14 days.

entry.text:
Entry by nationals of non-European Union (EU)/Schengen Area countries is banned through 30 September. Residents of EU and Schengen Area countries, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican, holders of long-term visas issued in EU member states and Schengen Area countries returning to the country of their residence, healthcare workers, transport workers and diplomatic personnel are exempt. Residents of Albania, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, China, Japan, Jordan, Moldova, New Zealand, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Ukraine, Hong Kong, Macau, Kosovo and Taiwan are also exempt. A negative test or proof of vaccination against COVID-19 is required for entry from the United Kingdom (UK). Proof of COVID-19 vaccination is required for non-essential travel from other non-EU countries.

Borders with other EU member states and Schengen countries are open.

Cruise ships are permitted to dock in Spanish ports.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Travellers arriving from high COVID-19 risk countries must present a certificate for a nucleic acid amplification test (PCR, TMA, LAMP, NEAR) taken within 72 hours or an antigen test that was taken within 48 hours before arrival; travellers who present proof of full vaccination against COVID-19 or recovery from a prior infection are exempt. The certificate must be in Spanish, English, French or German. The list of countries subject to testing will be updated weekly by health officials.

Transiting passengers are exempt from testing, provided that they do not leave the international zone. Travellers arriving from high-risk countries without a test result will be required to take a test upon arrival and subject to a fine of up to EUR6,000 (USD7,095).

Travellers arriving from the United Kingdom (UK) must present a negative nucleic acid amplification test that was taken within 72 hours before arrival or proof of full vaccination against the virus.
diseaseTesting.testType: PCR, NAAT, LAMP, TMA, NEAR, Antigen, PCR, NAAT, LAMP, TMA, NEAR

tracingApplication.text: "Radar Covid" is an optional mobile app for contact tracing.

mask.text: Wearing a face mask is compulsory in all indoor spaces, as well as crowded outdoor areas where a 1.5-metre minimum distance cannot be maintained among members of different households.

otherRestriction.text: All passengers arriving by air and sea will undergo a temperature check. Those suspected of having COVID-19 will be subject to an additional health assessment.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Fully vaccinated travellers are permitted entry regardless of purpose and exempt from COVID-19 testing. The vaccine must be approved by the European Medicines Agency (EMA) or the World Health Organization (WHO).

Travellers who recovered from a prior infection are exempt from pre-departure testing.

Accepted documentation include the EU Digital COVID Certificate or an equivalent certificate showing that at least 14 days have passed since the final dose or a positive nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) was issued between 11-180 days before arrival.
qualifiedVaccines: AstraZeneca (South Korea) - 14 days after second dose.
Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Sinopharm Phase 1 - 14 days after second dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 11 days, not older than 6 months.

areaPolicy.text: Regional authorities tightened COVID-19 measures following an increase in cases.

data.summary: The COVID-19 outbreak in Spain caused one of the highest number of deaths in Europe. In January 2021, the total number of cases in the country surpassed 2 million. While most restrictions have been eased following the end of the state of alarm in May 2021, thousands of new cases continue to be reported daily.

areaRestrictions.text: A negative COVID-19 test is required for travel to the Balearic Islands and the Canary Islands. Travellers who have recovered from COVID-19 or have been vaccinated against the virus are exempt.

Hundreds of demonstrators rallied on Puerta del Sol and outside the Assembly of Madrid in Puente de Vallecas on 27 September 2020 to protest lockdown measures in the capital. In October and November 2020, clashes erupted between demonstrators and police officers in Barcelona, Seville, Le√≥n, Logro√±o and Vitoria-Gasteiz during protests against the goverment's decision to impose a nighttime curfew. Further protests are possible, particularly in urban hubs.

transportation.text: International flights are operating at major airports, including Barcelona-El Prat (BCN/LEBL), Madrid‚ÄìBarajas (MAD/LEMD), Ibiza (IBZ/LEIB), Menorca (MAH/LEMH), Tenerife South (TFS/GCTS), Alicante-Elche (ALC/LEAL), Region of Murcia (RMU/LEMI), Sevilla (SVQ/LEZL), M√°laga (AGP/LEMG), Palma de Mallorca (PMI/LEPA) and Gran Canaria (LPA/GCLP).

declarationDocuments.text:
Travellers arriving by air must complete a health control form (https://www.spth.gob.es/) 48 hours prior to travel and obtain a QR code to present upon arrival. The form can be also completed on the mobile app "Spain Travel Health APP".

Travellers arriving by sea must complete a separate form (https://spthm.puertos.es/).

Travellers arriving in Galicia must provide contact details by completing a form (https://coronavirus.sergas.gal/viaxeiros/?ling=en) if they visited a high COVID-19 risk area in the last 14 days.

entry.text:
Entry by nationals of non-European Union (EU)/Schengen Area countries is banned through 30 September. Residents of EU and Schengen Area countries, Andorra, Monaco, San Marino and the Vatican, holders of long-term visas issued in EU member states and Schengen Area countries returning to the country of their residence, healthcare workers, transport workers and diplomatic personnel are exempt. Residents of Albania, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, China, Japan, Jordan, Moldova, New Zealand, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Ukraine, Hong Kong, Macau, Kosovo and Taiwan are also exempt. A negative test or proof of vaccination against COVID-19 is required for entry from the United Kingdom (UK). Proof of COVID-19 vaccination is required for non-essential travel from other non-EU countries.

Borders with other EU member states and Schengen countries are open.

Cruise ships are permitted to dock in Spanish ports.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Travellers arriving from high COVID-19 risk countries must present a certificate for a nucleic acid amplification test (PCR, TMA, LAMP, NEAR) taken within 72 hours or an antigen test that was taken within 48 hours before arrival; travellers who present proof of full vaccination against COVID-19 or recovery from a prior infection are exempt. The certificate must be in Spanish, English, French or German. The list of countries subject to testing will be updated weekly by health officials.

Transiting passengers are exempt from testing, provided that they do not leave the international zone. Travellers arriving from high-risk countries without a test result will be required to take a test upon arrival and subject to a fine of up to EUR6,000 (USD7,095).

Travellers arriving from the United Kingdom (UK) must present a negative nucleic acid amplification test that was taken within 72 hours before arrival or proof of full vaccination against the virus.

Travellers who recovered from a prior infection are exempt from pre-departure testing.

Accepted documentation include the EU Digital COVID Certificate or an equivalent certificate showing that at least 14 days have passed since the final dose or a positive nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) was issued between 11-180 days before arrival.

areaPolicy.text: Regional authorities tightened COVID-19 measures following an increase in cases.

data.summary: Health officials confirmed on 26 February 2020 that the first case of COVID-19 was detected in a patient in Thessaloniki who had recently returned from northern Italy. Following a countrywide lockdown, authorities began lifting restrictions in stages in May 2020 and allowed international travel to resume. Most COVID-19 lockdown measures were lifted on 14 May 2021; the country reopened to vaccinated travellers from most countries in a bit to resume tourism.

areaRestrictions.text: Until 06:00 local time on 16 September, a 01:00-06:00 local time curfew is in effect in Heraklion, Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Argolida and Evrytania regional units, and the municipality of Ikaria. Travel will be only permitted for going to work, attending a medical appointment or compelling reasons.

Officials extended restrictions on domestic flights until 13 September. Travel to and from the country's islands requires presenting a COVID-19 vaccination certificate with at least 14 days since the second dose, proof of recovery issued between 2-9 months before travel or a negative PCR test result no older than 72 hour or a rapid antigen test no older than 48 hours.

From 13 September, all unvaccinated individuals travelling by plane, boat, bus, or train must present a rapid antigen test no older than 48 hours before departure; tests will cost EUR10 (USD11,75).

Hospitality establishments are permitted to provide outdoor service. Restaurants, bars and nightlife establishments are permitted to provide service to seated guests only.

From 16 July-13 September, only fully vaccinated individuals will be allowed to enter indoor venues, including restaurants, cinemas and theatres.

Until 16 September, private gatherings with more than 20 people and music in public venues are not permitted in Heraklion, Achaia, Ilia, Messinia, Argolida and Evrytania regional units, and the municipality of Ikaria.

From 31 August, individuals must present either a proof of vaccination or a certificate about recent recovery from COVID-19 or a negative PCR test result issued within 72 hours to visit public venues, including exhibitions and conferences.

Starting 13 September, only those with proof of vaccination or recovery from COVID-19 will be permitted to enter indoor cafes, restaurants, clubs and sports venues. Customers without COVID-19 certificates must present a negative PCR test that was taken within 48 hours for entry to cinemas, theaters, museums and gyms. Unvaccinated university students must take COVID-19 tests twice a week. Rapid tests will cost 10EUR.

Police officers fired riot control agents to disperse demonstrators who rallied on Nea Smyrni Square in Athens on 7 March to protest police violence following earlier confrontations between officers and bystanders over the enforcement of COVID-19 social distancing restrictions. Protests have continued in other cities over the restrictions including Thessaloniki.

transportation.text: International flights are available at Athens (ATH/LGAV) and other airports across the country.

declarationDocuments.text: All international travellers must complete a Passenger Locator Form at least 24 hours before their planned travel.

entry.text:
Travellers from the European Union (EU) and the Schengen Area, as well as Albania, Andorra, Armenia, Australia, Azerbaijan, Bahrain, Belarus, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Brunei, Canada, China, Israel, Japan, Jordan, Kosovo, Kuwait, Lebanon, Moldova, Monaco, Montenegro, New Zealand, North Macedonia, Qatar, Russia, San Marino, Saudi Arabia, Serbia, Singapore, South Korea, Taiwan, Turkey, Ukraine, United Arab Emirates (UAE), United Kingdom (UK), United States (US) and the Vatican are permitted entry without quarantine, provided that they present proof of a negative test, full vaccination or recovery from COVID-19. Entry from other countries is only permitted for health professionals and others making essential travel.

Entry through land borders is possible through Promachonas, Ormenio, Evzonoi, Nymfaia, Niki, Doirani, Kristallopigi, Kipi, Kakavia, Kastanies and Exohi 24 hours a day.

Cruises and yachts are permitted, while maritime links with Turkey remain restricted.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Before travel

Arriving unvaccinated travellers from all countries must present a negative PCR test that was taken within 72 hours before arrival or a rapid antigen test no older than 48 hours before arrival, unless they have proof of vaccination or recovery from COVID-19.

Arrivals from Russia must present a negative COVID-19 test, regardless of vaccination status.

Upon arrival

Unvaccinated travellers arriving from Egypt, Albania, Argentina, Bulgaria, Brazil, Georgia, Cuba, United Arab Emirates, India, China, Libya, Morocco, North Macedonia, Pakistan, Russia and Turkey must take a rapid test upon arrival.

Random rapid antigen testing will be carried out at ports of entry; travellers who test positive must quarantine. Those who refuse health checks can be denied entry. Those who test positive at the country's land borders can be denied entry as well.

tracingApplication.text: There is no national contact tracing app.

quarantineModality.text:
Travellers from the European Union (EU) and the Schengen Area, as well as the United States (US), United Kingdom (UK), the United Arab Emirates (UAE), Serbia, Israel, Australia, New Zealand, South Korea, Singapore, North Macedonia, Canada, Belarus, Bahrain, Qatar, China, Kuwait, Turkey, Ukraine, Saudi Arabia, Russia, Bosnia-Herzegovina, Japan, Albania, Lebanon, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Brunei and Moldova, Andorra, Jordan, Kosovo, Monaco, San Marino, Taiwan and The Vatican are exempt from quarantine, provided that they present proof of a negative COVID-19 test result, full vaccination or recovery from the virus.

Travellers from Montenegro are exempt from quarantine, provided they present both a negative COVID-19 test result and a full vaccination certificate.

Those who test positive for COVID-19 during random testing at the border must quarantine at a designated hotel for up to 10 days, regardless of the country of departure. Vaccinated travellers who test positive must quarantine for seven days.

mask.text: Face masks must be worn in indoor spaces. Mask-wearing is mandatory in crowded public places; a fine of up to EUR300 (USD354) can be imposed for non-compliance.

exit.text: There are no special requirements to exit the country, with the exception of a Passenger Locator Form that all international travellers must complete.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Vaccinated travellers are exempt from quarantine and testing, provided that they present proof of full vaccination. At least 14 days must have passed since the final dose. As of 30 June, testing requirements will be reinstituted for vaccinated travellers from Russia.

Proof of recovery from COVID-19 must have been issued between 2-9 months prior to travel for exemption from testing and quarantine.

All documentation must have been issued in English, German French, Italian, Spanish or Russian.

Residents who have been vaccinated against COVID-19, recovered from a prior infection or recently tested negative for the virus can obtain EU Digital COVID Certificates on the government portal (https://www.gov.gr/ipiresies/ugeia-kai-pronoia/koronoios-covid-19/greencertificate).
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.
Sinopharm Phase 1 - 14 days after second dose.
Sputnik V - 14 days after second dose.
Immunity through previous infection - positive test older than 60 days, not older than 9 months.

areaPolicy.text: High COVID-19 incidence areas are subject to stricter measures, including a nightly curfew.

data.summary: Public health officials confirmed the first two COVID-19 cases in England on 31 January 2020. While a mass vaccination campaign has significantly reduced the number of deaths, the country has seen a sharp uptick in COVID-19 cases driven by the spread of the delta virus variant. Despite high incidence rates, most distancing measures have been lifted.

areaRestrictions.text:
Covid domestic travel policies and advice for:

  • England
  • Scotland
  • Wales
  • Northern Ireland

Northern Ireland

Up to 15 people from four households are permitted to gather in a domestic setting. A one-metre minimum distancing is mandatory in indoor venues.

Scotland

Starting 1 October, a COVID-19 health pass will be required for entering nightlife establishments and large public events. The requirement is expected to apply to unseated indoor live events with more than 500 people in the audience, unseated outdoor live events with more than 4,000 people in the audience and events of any kind with more than 10,000 people present.
Large rallies that have ended in clashes with police have been held in London, Belfast, Manchester, Edinburgh, Leeds, Glasgow, Brighton and other cities to protest lockdown measures.

transportation.text:
Most available long-haul flights are operating at London Heathrow Airport (LHR/EGLL). Multiple carriers including British Airways are gradually increasing their flight schedule.

Flights from Argentina, Bangladesh, Brazil, Cape Verde, Chile, Cuba, Dominican Republic, Egypt, Ethiopia, Indonesia, Kenya, Maldives, Oman, Pakistan, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Tunisia or Turkey are permitted to land at dedicated terminals of London Heathrow (LHR/EGLL) or Birmingham International (BHX/EGBB) airports only.

British Airways suspended all passenger flights between the United Kingdom and Mexico from 15 August to 30 September.

declarationDocuments.text: Arriving travellers must complete and submit a passenger locator form within 48 hours before arrival. Travellers who are arriving from Ireland, the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man and stayed there for at least 10 days are not required to complete the form.

entry.text:
Those who have travelled to or through Afghanistan, Angola, Argentina, Bangladesh, Bolivia, Botswana, Brazil, Burundi, Cape Verde, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Cuba, Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Egypt, Eritrea, Eswatini, Ethiopia, French Guiana, Georgia, Guyana, Haiti, Kenya, Lesotho, Malawi, Maldives, Mayotte, Mexico, Mongolia, Montenegro, Mozambique, Myanmar, Namibia, Nepal, Oman, Pakistan, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Philippines, Reuniion, Rwanda, Seychelles, Sierra Leone, Somalia, South Africa, Sri Lanka, Sudan, Suriname, Tanzania, Thailand, Trinidad and Tobago, Tunisia, Turkey, Uganda, Uruguay, Venezuela, Zambia or Zimbabwe in the last 10 days are not permitted to enter.

Only nationals of the UK and Ireland, UK permanent residents and UK long-term visa holders will be permitted entry from these countries.

diseaseTesting.text:
Before travel

Arriving travellers must present a negative COVID-19 test result not older than three days before the time of departure, regardless of vaccination status. Arrivals from the Common Travel Area (Jersey, Guernsey, the Isle of Man and Ireland), children under the age of 11 and hauliers are exempt. Consult the government website for a full list of testing exemptions (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules).

After arrival

Travellers must book a post-arrival COVID-19 testing package online (https://quarantinehotelbookings.ctmportal.co.uk/) at their own expense.

Travellers returning from "green list" countries must take an additional PCR test on or before day 2 after arrival. Vaccinated UK travellers returning from abroad and vaccinated travellers from the United States and the European Union must also take a Day 2 test.

Other travellers arriving from an "amber list" country and all travellers returning from a "red list" country must take PCR tests on days 2 and 8 during quarantine.

As part of the 'test to release' scheme, travellers arriving in England from an "amber list" country can take a COVID-19 test five days after entry to shorten the self-quarantine period. Travellers wishing to be tested must do so at their own expense. Travellers must continue to take COVID-19 tests on day 2 and 8 of their stay, regardless of the test result taken as part of the 'test to release' scheme. Travellers arriving from "red list" countries are excluded from the scheme.

tracingApplication.text: Optional contact tracing app "NHS COVID-19" is available for use in England and Wales, "StopCOVID NI" in Northern Ireland and "Protect Scotland" in Scotland.

quarantineModality.text:
Quarantine is mandatory for travellers, excluding those arriving from "green list" areas and vaccinated travellers arriving from some "amber list" areas. For travel from Portugal, quarantine exemptions only apply to arrivals from the Azores or Madeira.

Travellers from "amber list" countries must quarantine for 10 days at home. Vaccinated UK travellers returning from abroad and vaccinated travellers arriving from "amber" countries in the European Union (EU) or the United States (US) are exempt from quarantine.

Travellers who arrive from or stayed in "red list" countries must undergo hotel quarantine at a designated facility for 10 days. The requirement also applies to those who transited through a "red list" country. Travellers arriving from "red list" countries must book a hotel and testing package at their own expense (https://quarantinehotelbookings.ctmportal.co.uk/). The quarantine costs GBP1,750 for the first traveller staying in a room.

Workers in healthcare and other select sectors are exempt from quarantine. Consult the government website (https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules/coronavirus-covid-19-travellers-exempt-from-uk-border-rules) for further details on quarantine requirements by sector.

England

As part of the "test to release" scheme, travellers may opt to take a test five days into their self-quarantine and leave early, pending a negative test result within 24-48 hours. The testing scheme is not available to travellers arriving from "red list" countries subject to entry bans.

mask.text:
Wearing a face mask is mandatory in public transport and other enclosed public spaces in Northern Ireland, Scotland and Wales.

In England, the use of face masks is recommended in crowded areas. Businesses and travel operators can set their own mask requirements. The use of face masks remains mandatory on public transport operated by Transport for London (TfL).

British Airways passengers are asked to wear a mask from the moment they arrive at the airport until they leave the plane at their destination.

diseaseVaccination.text:
Fully vaccinated travellers arriving from "amber" countries are exempt from quarantine, provided that they were vaccinated in the United Kingdom (UK), an EU member state, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, Switzerland, Vatican City or the United States (US). The vaccine must be recognised by the Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), US Food and Drug Administration (FDA), European Medicines Agency (EMA) or Swissmedic. To be considered fully vaccinated, travellers must have received two doses of the same vaccine and at least 14 days must have passed since the final dose. Travellers who received one dose of an approved single-dose vaccine are also considered fully vaccinated.

Fully vaccinated travellers arriving from all countries must continue to be tested before departure and on Day 2 after arrival.

Those travelling abroad from Wales or England can present the NHS Covid Pass (https://www.nhs.uk/conditions/coronavirus-covid-19/covid-pass/get-your-covid-pass-letter/) as a digital app or in a letter form as proof of full vaccination from COVID-19. Those travelling from Northern Ireland (https://www.nidirect.gov.uk/services/coronavirus-covid-19-interim-proof-vaccination-document) or Scotland (https://www.nhsinform.scot/covid19status) can obtain the certificate in written form.
qualifiedVaccines: Johnson & Johnson - 14 days after first dose.

areaPolicy.text: Most social distancing measures were lifted in August 2021.
